results.Policy Text: GSA Public Buildings Service PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin 23-01 PUBLIC BUILDINGS SERVICE REGIONAL COMMISSIONERS ACQUISITION DIRECTORS TRACY MARCINOWSKI ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER OFFICE OF ACQUISITION MANAGEMENT (PQ) Mandatory Use of the Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH) Tool Date: MEMORANDUM FOR: FROM: SUBJECT: 1. Purpose The purpose of this Procurement Instructional Bulletin (PIB) is to outline the guidelines for implementation and use of the Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH) tool. 2. Background The Skill Enhancement & Employee Development (SEED) program was created to provide the 1102 contract specialist community with a solid foundation, minimize acquisition skill gaps, and increase the overall knowledge and skills of the acquisition workforce. As part of SEED, the PATH tool was developed to give those in the 1102 acquisition community with little to no contracting knowledge a tool to learn and test their knowledge using scenario based exercises. The tool consists of various exercises categorized into the following modules: Pre-Award, Award, Post-Award, and Other. 3. Effective Date This PIB is effective on the date signed. The exercises that make up the training tool will be updated, as needed, to address any regulatory changes or Office of Acquisition Management (OAM) policy guidance 1800 F Street, NW Washington, DC 20405-0002 www.gsa.gov DocuSign Envelope ID: 3DF787F3-F9CB-4240-B6F6-E46C4D13456610/28/2022 revisions. 4. Cancellation Date This PIB will remain in effect until canceled. 5. Affected or Canceled Policies None. 6. Applicability This PIB applies to all Public Buildings Service (PBS) 1102s, including interns hired under the PBS Acquisition Intern Program. Use of the PATH tool is mandatory for new employees at the GS-09 level and below who are hired on or after the effective date of this tool. The tool is optional for those employees above the GS-09 level. 7. Exceptions The requirements of this PIB will not be applicable to employees who are participating under the Emerging Leaders Program (ELP), until they are converted to the 1102 series. 8. Instructions and Procedures Exercises & Answer Keys The exercises are broken into four modules: Pre-award, Award, Post-Award, and Other. There are two documents for each topic: the exercise and answer key. Links to all of the documents can be found on Attachment 1 - PATH Tool Table of Contents. Users should complete the exercises in chronological order. Some exercises have a service and construction type scenario. In those cases, users can elect to complete one or both exercises. The users will access the exercise, read the scenario, if one is included, and use the policy and guidance references to answer the questions. Only the regional supervisors will have access to the answer key documents. Upon completion of each exercise, users must work with their supervisor, or designee, to review their responses and compare them to the answer key. This will help ensure that users understand the general concepts of the exercise topic. 2 DocuSign Envelope ID: 3DF787F3-F9CB-4240-B6F6-E46C4D134566 New employees will be expected to complete the entire tool within 18 months of their start date. At a minimum, the first module (Pre-Award) is to be completed within the first year. FAI CSOD & CLPs Upon completion of all exercises in a module, users are to ensure that their completion is indicated in FAI Cornerstone OnDemand (CSOD). To do this, supervisors are to complete the survey form linked as Attachment 2 - PATH Tool Supervisor Confirmation of Completion. Upon receipt, OAM will update FAI CSOD. This must be done for completion of each module. OAM will use this information to track completion of the tool. This process will also assist to provide continuous learning points (CLPs) to users who are eligible to receive them. 9. Point of Contact Any questions regarding the content of this PIB may be directed to Gabriela Sanchez, Procurement Analyst, Office of Acquisition Management, by email at gabriela.sanchez@gsa.gov. 10. Here's a comprehensive policy analysis:

1. Policy Summary (PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin 23-01):
- Establishes mandatory use of the Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH) tool
- Applies to Public Buildings Service (PBS) contract specialists (1102 series)
- Focuses on skill enhancement and employee development for acquisition workforce
- Mandatory for new employees at GS-09 level and below
- Requires completion of training modules within 18 months of start date

2. Executive Order Summary:
- Rescinds numerous previous executive orders related to various federal policies
- Focuses on removing diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives
- Directs agency heads to end implementation of what it terms "unlawful and radical DEI ideology"
- Requires review of previous administrative actions

3. Applicability Analysis:
- The executive order does NOT directly impact the PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin
- The PATH tool is a professional training program focused on acquisition skills
- The policy does not appear to contain DEI-specific language or components that would trigger the executive order's rescission requirements

4. Recommended Next Steps:
- No immediate action required for this specific policy
- Continue normal implementation of the PATH tool training program
- Maintain standard documentation and tracking of employee training completions
- Consult with GSA legal counsel if any uncertainty remains about policy compliance

Recommendation: Continue current policy implementation without modifications.

Note: This analysis is based on a careful review of the documents and represents a professional, objective assessment of potential impacts. Always consult official GSA guidance for definitive interpretations.

Of course. As a policy analyst for the General Services Administration, I can provide an analysis of the provided documents.

Here is a summary of my findings.

***

**TO:** GSA Leadership
**FROM:** GSA Policy Analyst
**DATE:** [Current Date]
**SUBJECT:** Analysis of Executive Order 14148 Impact on PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin 23-01 (Mandatory Use of PATH Tool)

### 1. Summary of Policy Text (PIB 23-01)
The policy, Procurement Instructional Bulletin (PIB) 23-01, establishes the mandatory use of the Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH) tool for all new GSA Public Buildings Service (PBS) employees in the 1102 contract specialist series at the GS-09 level and below. The PATH tool is part of the broader Skill Enhancement & Employee Development (SEED) program and is designed to provide foundational knowledge in government contracting through scenario-based exercises. The training modules cover the full acquisition lifecycle: Pre-Award, Award, and Post-Award. The policy is operational and focuses on ensuring a baseline level of technical competence for junior acquisition professionals.

### 2. Summary of Executive Order Text (EO 14148)
Executive Order 14148, "Initial Rescissions of Harmful Executive Orders and Actions," revokes several executive orders from the previous administration. The stated purpose is to remove policies related to "diversity, equity, and inclusion" (DEI), immigration, and "climate extremism," which the order describes as harmful. Specifically, the EO revokes E.O. 13985 ("Advancing Racial Equity and Support for Underserved Communities"), among others. The order’s focus is on rescinding high-level, government-wide policy directives and the principles they established.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Applicability
This executive order **does not directly apply to or invalidate** the policy outlined in PIB 23-01. The reasoning is as follows:

*   **Different Scopes:** The PIB is a procedural, internal GSA policy focused on technical skills training for a specific job series (1102 Contract Specialist). Its purpose is to ensure employee competency in the mechanics of federal procurement. The Executive Order, conversely, targets broad, government-wide policy frameworks, particularly those related to DEI, that influence the goals and principles of federal actions.
*   **No Direct Linkage:** PIB 23-01 and the PATH tool it mandates are not established by or derived from any of the Executive Orders revoked by EO 14148. The SEED program and PATH tool are internal GSA initiatives aimed at professional development and closing skill gaps, a standard function of a federal agency. The policy text contains no language related to DEI, racial equity, or underserved communities.
*   **Content vs. Mandate:** The Executive Order could potentially influence the *content* of future federal acquisition regulations (e.g., the FAR), which in turn could necessitate updates to the training scenarios within the PATH tool. For example, if regulations derived from E.O. 13985 are changed, a training scenario based on those specific regulations would need to be revised. However, this does not affect the validity of the PIB itself, which is the mandate *to use the tool* for training. The PIB wisely anticipates this by stating, "The exercises that make up the training tool will be updated, as needed, to address any regulatory changes."

In summary, the policy mandating the use of a skills-based training tool is unaffected. The potential impact is secondary, relating only to the specific content of the training exercises, which are designed to be updated as regulations change.

### 4. Next Steps to Achieve Compliance
While the policy itself is not affected and requires no revision, prudent action should be taken to ensure the content of the training tool remains compliant with the new federal policy landscape.

1.  **No Action Required for PIB 23-01:** The bulletin can remain in effect as written.
2.  **Content Review of the PATH Tool:** The Office of Acquisition Management (OAM), as the responsible office, should initiate a review of the scenarios and exercises within all PATH modules (Pre-Award, Award, Post-Award, Other).
3.  **Identify and Update Content:** The review should identify any training content, examples, or scenarios that are based specifically on policies, programs, or guidance originating from the now-revoked Executive Order 13985. Any such content should be updated to reflect current regulations and policy. This action falls within the existing process described in Section 3 of the PIB.

Final Determination: Not Affected

Final Decision: [Affected]

Full Justification:
1.  **The specific domain/subject area of the policy:** The policy, "PBS Procurement Instructional Bulletin 23-01," falls within the domain of **federal acquisition workforce training and professional development**. Its specific purpose is to mandate the use of the "Professional Acquisition Training Highway (PATH)" tool for the 1102 contract specialist community within the General Services Administration (GSA). The goal is to standardize training, enhance skills, and close knowledge gaps in federal procurement.

2.  **The specific domain/subject area of the executive order:** The executive order, "Initial Rescissions of Harmful Executive Orders and Actions," is a broad, government-wide directive aimed at **reversing specific policy priorities of the previous administration**. It explicitly targets and seeks to eliminate policies, practices, and programs related to "diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI)," certain immigration policies, and "climate extremism." Its central focus is on federal personnel and management practices that it claims have replaced merit with "a divisive and dangerous preferential hierarchy."

3.  **Detailed analysis of whether there is direct or indirect impact:** While there is no direct, explicit contradiction between the texts, the executive order has a clear **indirect impact** on the policy. The policy mandates a training program (PATH) in the field of federal procurement. Federal procurement is a domain heavily intertwined with regulations and goals that are often categorized under the umbrella of DEI, such as programs for small disadvantaged businesses, women-owned small businesses, and other set-asides aimed at promoting equity in government contracting.

    The executive order's stated intent to remove the "injection of 'diversity, equity, and inclusion' (DEI) into our institutions" would almost certainly trigger a review of all training materials for federal acquisition professionals. The content of the PATH tool, which this policy mandates, would be scrutinized to ensure it aligns with the new administration's anti-DEI stance. Any training modules, scenarios, or guidance related to equitable procurement or supplier diversity would be subject to revision or removal. Because the policy's sole function is to enforce the use of this tool, any substantive changes to the tool's content directly affect the implementation and substance of the policy itself.

4.  **Key language or provisions that support your determination:**
    *   **Policy Text:** The policy supports the "Skill Enhancement & Employee Development (SEED) program" and mandates the "PATH tool" to give the "1102 acquisition community... a tool to learn and test their knowledge." This establishes a mandatory training regime in the procurement field.
    *   **EO Text:** The order targets the "injection of 'diversity, equity, and inclusion' (DEI) into our institutions" which it claims has "corrupted them by replacing hard work, merit, and equality with a divisive and dangerous preferential hierarchy."
    *   **The Link:** The EO's sweeping language against DEI "practices... embedded within every agency" applies directly to training programs that instruct federal employees on how to implement procurement laws. Since federal procurement law contains provisions that could be interpreted by the new administration as DEI-related, the training content is a clear target for review under the EO. Therefore, the policy mandating the training is affected.

5.  **Any nuances or edge cases considered in your assessment:** The initial "Not Affected" flag likely resulted from a narrow reading of the policy text, which, on its face, is neutral and focuses only on skills and knowledge. However, this assessment fails to consider the context of the subject matter. A policy does not have to explicitly mention "DEI" to be affected by an order that targets DEI. By mandating a program in a field where DEI principles are actively practiced (federal contracting), the policy's implementation becomes contingent on the EOs directives. The bulletin itself might not be rescinded, but the program it mandates will be reviewed and likely altered, thus affecting the policy's execution and intent.

Purpose. Federal regulations should not predetermine economic winners and losers. Yet some regulations operate to exclude new market entrants. Regulations that reduce competition, entrepreneurship, and innova- tion as well as the benefits they create for American consumers should be eliminated. This order commences the process for eliminating anti-com- petitive regulations to revitalize the American economy. Sec. 2. Definitions. (a)  Agency  has the meaning given to it in section 3502 of title 44, United States Code, except that it does not include the Executive Office of the President or any components thereof. (b)  Agency head  means the highest-ranking official of an agency, such as the Secretary, Administrator, Chairman, or Director, unless otherwise specified in this order. Sec. 3. Rescinding Anti-Competitive Regulations. (a) Agency heads shall, in consultation with the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission (Chair- man) and the Attorney General, complete a review of all regulations subject to their rulemaking authority and identify those that: (i) create, or facilitate the creation of, de facto or de jure monopolies; (ii) create unnecessary barriers to entry for new market participants; (iii) limit competition between competing entities or have the effect of limiting competition between competing entities; (iv) create or facilitate licensure or accreditation requirements that unduly limit competition; (v) unnecessarily burden the agency s procurement processes, thereby lim- iting companies  ability to compete for procurements; or (vi) otherwise impose anti-competitive restraints or distortions on the oper- ation of the free market. (b) Within 70 days of the date of this order, agency heads shall each provide to the Chairman and the Attorney General a list of regulations identified by the categories specified in subsection (a) of this section. Agency heads shall also include a recommendation as to whether each of the listed regulations warrants rescission or modification in light of its anti-competitive effects. For recommended modifications, agency heads shall briefly specify what modification is appropriate. For regulations that are anti-competitive by design, agency heads shall provide a justification for their anti-competitive effects if the agency head is not proposing rescission or modification. (c) In conducting the review required by subsection (a) of this section, agency heads shall prioritize review of those rules that satisfy the definition of  significant regulatory action  in Executive Order 12866 of September 30, 1993 (Regulatory Planning and Review), as amended. (d) Within 10 days of the date of this order, the Chairman shall issue a request for information (RFI) that seeks public input on the identification of regulations that fall within the categories specified in subsection (a) of this section, as well as comments explaining the proposed classifications. The request shall remain open for 40 days. Policy Analysis Summary

1. Policy Text Summary:
The GSA memorandum dated January 13, 2023, provides guidance on the Fiscal Year 2023 Capital Investment Program. Key points include:
- Total Capital Budget of $2,159,893,000
- Increased escalation authority from 10% to 20% for New Construction and Acquisition (BA51) and Major Repairs and Alterations (BA55) projects
- Detailed funding allocations for various construction and renovation projects
- Guidance on project procurement and approval processes

2. Executive Order Summary:
Executive Order 14267 (April 9, 2025) aims to:
- Reduce anti-competitive regulatory barriers
- Require agencies to review and identify regulations that:
  a) Create monopolies
  b) Limit market competition
  c) Create unnecessary entry barriers
  d) Impose anti-competitive restraints
- Mandate a comprehensive review of existing regulations
- Establish a process for potential rescission or modification of anti-competitive regulations

3. Applicability of Executive Order:
The executive order DOES apply to this GSA policy for the following reasons:
- The policy involves procurement and investment processes
- The escalation authority and project approval mechanisms could potentially be viewed as creating regulatory barriers
- The order specifically targets regulations that might limit competition in government processes

4. Recommended Next Steps for Compliance:
a) Conduct a thorough review of the Capital Investment Program guidelines
b) Assess how current escalation authorities and project approval processes might create market entry barriers
c) Prepare documentation justifying the current regulatory approach
d) Be prepared to provide detailed explanations of how current processes:
   - Do not unduly limit market competition
   - Ensure fair and open procurement
   - Provide equal opportunities for different market participants
e) Collaborate with the Federal Trade Commission and Attorney General's office to validate the current regulatory approach
f) Be ready to modify guidelines if anti-competitive elements are identified

Recommendation: While the current policy appears to provide flexibility (20% escalation authority), a proactive review should be conducted to ensure full compliance with the executive order's intent of promoting market competition.
results.updated_summary: The executive order's focus on reducing regulatory barriers directly impacts the GSA's Capital Investment Program by mandating a review of potential anti-competitive elements in procurement and project approval processes. The policy's escalation authorities and approval mechanisms will need careful examination to ensure they do not inadvertently limit market competition.

TO: GSA Leadership
FROM: GSA Policy Analyst
DATE: October 26, 2023
SUBJECT: Analysis of Executive Order 14267's Impact on the FY 2023 Capital Investment Program Execution Guidance Memorandum

This memorandum provides an analysis of Executive Order 14267, "Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers," and its effect on the GSA internal policy memorandum titled "Increased 20% Escalation Authority Update FY 2023 Capital Investment Program Execution Guidance."

### 1. Summary of the Policy Text

The GSA policy document is an internal memorandum dated January 13, 2023. It provides financial and execution guidance to GSA regional directors regarding the FY 2023 Capital Investment Program. The memo details the discrepancy between the President's Budget Request ($2.16B) and the final appropriated amount from Congress ($1.47B). It provides specific instructions on the status of funding allotments, the lifting of Continuing Resolution guidance, and the process for handling project funds, particularly for prospectus projects pending full-year apportionment and congressional approvals. The document is administrative and procedural in nature, focused on internal budget execution and project management based on a specific congressional appropriation.

### 2. Summary of the Executive Order Text

Executive Order 14267, issued on April 9, 2025, directs federal agencies to eliminate anti-competitive regulations. Its stated purpose is to remove rules that exclude new market entrants, limit competition, and stifle innovation. The order mandates that agency heads review all regulations under their authority and identify those that create monopolies, establish unnecessary barriers to entry, limit competition, impose undue licensure requirements, or unnecessarily burden the agency's procurement processes. The clear intent is to scrutinize public-facing rules that govern how private entities interact with the government and compete in the marketplace.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Applicability

The Executive Order **does not apply** to this specific GSA policy memorandum. The analysis is based on the fundamental distinction between a "regulation" as targeted by the Executive Order and an "internal policy/guidance document" like the GSA memorandum.

*   **Scope of the Executive Order:** E.O. 14267 is focused on "regulations." In a federal context, this term typically refers to formal rules of general applicability and future effect, issued by an agency to implement, interpret, or prescribe law or policy. These regulations are usually codified in the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) and impact the public, private industry, or other external stakeholders. The EO's criteria, such as creating "barriers to entry for new market participants" or burdening "procurement processes," clearly target the rules that govern how external companies do business with or are regulated by the government.

*   **Nature of the GSA Policy:** The GSA document in question is not a regulation. It is an internal memorandum providing administrative and budgetary guidance to GSA employees. It does not establish any rules for private companies, set new procurement policies, or create licensure requirements. It is an operational document that communicates the status of congressionally appropriated funds and directs internal GSA components on how to manage these funds for specific, named projects (e.g., U.S. Courthouses). It does not alter the underlying procurement regulations (such as the Federal Acquisition Regulation or the GSA Acquisition Manual) that companies must follow to compete for GSA contracts.

While GSA's formal procurement *regulations* would be subject to a review under E.O. 14267 (specifically under Sec. 3(a)(v)), this internal memo on budget execution is not one of those regulations.

### 4. Next Steps to Achieve Compliance

Because this specific policy document is not affected by the Executive Order, no direct action or modification is required for this memorandum.

However, as a general matter of compliance with E.O. 14267, GSA should:
1.  Initiate a broader, agency-wide review of its formal, public-facing regulations, particularly those codified in the GSA Acquisition Manual (GSAM) and other parts of the CFR under GSA's authority.
2.  Establish a process, in consultation with the Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General as required by the EO, to identify any regulations that may create unnecessary burdens on competition in GSA's procurement processes.
3.  Report the findings of that comprehensive review as mandated by the Executive Order.

This specific memorandum would not be part of that review.

---

**Final Determination: Not Affected**

1.  **The specific domain/subject area of the policy:** The policy, "FY 2023 Capital Investment Program Execution Memorandum," is an internal government administrative and fiscal document. Its domain is federal budget execution and public administration. Key language such as "Capital Investment Program Execution Guidance," "Consolidated Appropriations Act," "New Obligational Authority (NOA)," and "allotment of funds in Pegasys" confirms that this memorandum's purpose is to provide guidance to U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) regional offices on how to manage and obligate the capital funds appropriated by Congress for fiscal year 2023.

2.  **The specific domain/subject area of the executive order:** The executive order, "Reducing Anti-Competitive Regulatory Barriers," operates in the domain of economic policy and regulatory reform. Its stated purpose is to "eliminate anti-competitive regulations" that "exclude new market entrants" and "reduce competition, entrepreneurship, and innovation." This order directs federal agencies to review and change formal regulations that govern economic activity and impact market competition.

3.  **Detailed analysis of whether there is direct or indirect impact:** There is no direct or indirect impact from the executive order on this specific policy memorandum. The policy is an internal directive concerning the management of appropriated funds, while the executive order targets external-facing regulations that shape market behavior.
    *   **No Direct Impact:** The GSA memorandum does not create, modify, or enforce any market regulations. It is an internal administrative communication about budget execution. The EO, conversely, does not address the internal budgetary or financial management processes of federal agencies.
    *   **No Indirect Impact:** While the regulations governing how GSA *spends* its capital investment funds (e.g., procurement and contracting rules in the Federal Acquisition Regulation) could potentially be subject to review under this EO, this specific memorandum *is not* one of those regulations. It is a document that executes the budget *within* the existing regulatory framework. It concerns the "what" and "how much" of funding, not the "rules" of competition for that funding.

4.  **Key language or provisions that support your determination:**
    *   **Policy Language:** The policy text is focused entirely on fiscal matters: "GSA’s FY 2023 Capital totaled $2,159,893,000," "appropriated $1,470,089,000 of New Obligational Authority," and "auto-allotment of funds." This confirms its nature as a financial execution document.
    *   **EO Language:** The EO explicitly targets "Federal regulations" and seeks to eliminate those that are "anti-competitive." This focus on "regulations" as the object of reform is critical. The GSA document is a "memorandum," not a regulation that binds the public or market participants.

5.  **Any nuances or edge cases considered in your assessment:** The primary nuance is the distinction between a policy document and the broader regulatory framework it operates within. One might argue that the *process* of capital investment itself could have competitive implications. However, this specific policy document is not the source of those rules. It is a communication about the allocation of funds *after* they have been appropriated by Congress. results.EO_Text: Federal Register Vol. 90, No. 71 Tuesday, April 15, 2025 Title 3  The President Presidential Documents 15615 Executive Order 14263 of April 9, 2025 Addressing Risks From Susman Godfrey By the authority vested in me as President by the Constitution and the laws of the United States of America, it is hereby ordered: Section 1. Background. Lawyers and law firms that engage in activities detrimental to critical American interests should not have access to our Nation s secrets, nor should their conduct be subsidized by Federal taxpayer funds or contracts. My Administration must also take appropriate and nec- essary measures to guard against the actual, potential, or perceived conflicts of interest that arise when the Government funds, engages with, or otherwise devotes resources to law firms and their clients that engage in conduct undermining critical American interests and priorities. I have determined that action is necessary to address the significant risks, egregious conduct, and conflicts of interest associated with Susman Godfrey LLP (Susman). Susman spearheads efforts to weaponize the American legal system and degrade the quality of American elections. Susman also funds groups that engage in dangerous efforts to undermine the effectiveness of the United States military through the injection of political and radical ideology, and it supports efforts to discriminate on the basis of race. Susman itself engages in unlawful discrimination, including discrimination on the basis of race. For example, Susman administers a program where it offers financial awards and employment opportunities only to  students of color.  My Administration is committed to ending such unlawful discrimi- nation perpetrated in the name of  diversity, equity, and inclusion  policies and ensuring that Federal benefits support the laws and policies of the United States, including those laws and policies promoting our national security and respecting the democratic process. Those who engage in blatant discrimination and other activities inconsistent with the interests of the United States should not have access to our Nation s secrets nor be deemed responsible stewards of any Federal funds. Sec. 2. Security Clearance Review. (a) The Attorney General, the Director of National Intelligence, and all other relevant heads of executive departments and agencies (agencies) shall immediately take steps consistent with applica- ble law to suspend any active security clearances held by individuals at Susman, pending a review of whether such clearances are consistent with the national interest. (b) The Office of Management and Budget shall identify all Government goods, property, material, and services, including Sensitive Compartmented Information Facilities, provided for the benefit of Susman. The heads of agencies providing such material or services shall, to the extent permitted by law, expeditiously cease such provision. Sec. 3. Contracting. TO: GSA Leadership, Public Buildings Service (PBS)
FROM: GSA Policy Analyst
DATE: October 26, 2023
SUBJECT: Analysis of Executive Order 14263 on GSA COR Desk Guide for Building Services

This memorandum provides an analysis of Executive Order 14263, "Addressing Risks From Susman Godfrey," and its impact on the GSA COR Desk Guide for Building Services Contracts.

### 1. Summary of Policy Text

The "U.S. General Services Administration COR Desk Guide | Building Services Contracts" is an internal GSA operational document. It serves as a procedural manual for GSA's Contracting Officer's Representatives (CORs). The guide outlines the roles, responsibilities, and specific procedures for administering and managing building services contracts within the Public Buildings Service (PBS), covering areas like contract oversight, performance monitoring, and compliance. It is a "how-to" guide for GSA personnel managing existing contracts.

### 2. Summary of Executive Order Text

Executive Order 14263, issued on April 9, 2025, directs the Executive Branch to cease providing federal funds or contracts to the law firm Susman Godfrey LLP. The order's rationale is based on the administration's determination that the firm engages in activities detrimental to American interests, including undermining the legal and electoral systems, funding groups that harm military effectiveness, and practicing unlawful racial discrimination. The EO effectively prohibits federal agencies from engaging in or continuing contractual relationships with this specific entity.

### 3. Detailed Explanation of Applicability

Yes, this executive order directly applies to and affects the policy and procedures outlined in the GSA COR Desk Guide. While the EO does not amend the text of the Desk Guide itself, it imposes a new, substantive requirement that all GSA contracting personnel, including the CORs who use this guide, must follow.

The relationship is as follows:

*   **Substantive Prohibition:** The Executive Order creates a government-wide, substantive prohibition against contracting with a specific entity (Susman Godfrey LLP).
*   **Procedural Implementation:** The COR Desk Guide outlines the procedures for contract administration. The actions of the CORs and Contracting Officers who follow this guide are now governed by this new prohibition. For example, any procedures in the guide related to contractor selection, option year renewals, or processing payments would now have to include a verification step to ensure the contractor is not the prohibited entity.
*   **Implied Duty:** The guide details the COR's responsibility to ensure contractor compliance with laws and regulations. An Executive Order from the President is a binding directive for the Executive Branch; therefore, ensuring compliance with EO 14263 falls within the scope of a COR's duties.

Although it is unlikely that a law firm like Susman Godfrey would hold a "Building Services" contract with PBS, the GSA's contracting authority is broad. The prohibition is agency-wide and applies to all types of contracts. Therefore, the procedures used by PBS personnel must be updated to account for this directive. The current Desk Guide is now incomplete as it lacks guidance on how to comply with this specific prohibition.

### 4. Next Steps to Achieve Compliance

To ensure GSA's PBS contracting operations are in full compliance with EO 14263, the following steps are recommended:

1.  **Immediate Notification:** Issue an immediate bulletin to all PBS Contracting Officers (COs), Contract Specialists, and CORs, informing them of the EO and the prohibition on awarding or funding contracts with Susman Godfrey LLP.
2.  **System-Wide Vendor Check:** GSA must perform a comprehensive review of all current contracts and vendor databases (including GSA Schedules) to identify if Susman Godfrey LLP is a prime or significant subcontractor on any existing GSA contract vehicle. If found, coordinate immediately with the Office of General Counsel (OGC) to determine the appropriate contractual remedies, which may include termination for convenience or cause.
3.  **Update the COR Desk Guide:** The Desk Guide and other relevant acquisition manuals must be updated. Revisions should include a new section on "Compliance with Executive Orders and Prohibited Entities Lists," specifically referencing EO 14263 and establishing a standard procedure for checking contractor eligibility against such directives during all phases of the contract lifecycle.
4.  **Incorporate into Checklists:** Add a mandatory check-box item to all relevant contract administration checklists (e.g., pre-award surveys, option year renewals, final payment processing) to verify the contractor is not on a list of prohibited entities established by law or Executive Order.
5.  **Coordinate with OGC:** Engage GSA's Office of General Counsel to develop standardized language and official implementation guidance for all GSA acquisition personnel.

Final Determination: [Affected]

**Full Justification:**

1.  **The specific domain/subject area of the policy:**
    The policy, "COR Desk Guide | Building Services Contracts," operates in the domain of **federal contract administration and management**. Specifically, it is an operational guide for U.S. General Services Administration (GSA) personnel, known as Contracting Officer's Representatives (CORs), who are responsible for the post-award oversight of contracts for building services. Its focus is on the procedural aspects of managing an existing contract.

2.  **The specific domain/subject area of the executive order:**
    The executive order, "Addressing Risks from Susman Godfrey," operates in the domain of **federal procurement eligibility, ethics, and national security**. It establishes a new government-wide restriction that prohibits federal funds and contracts from being awarded to a specific law firm (and potentially others) deemed to be engaging in activities detrimental to U.S. interests. Its focus is on determining *who* is eligible to receive a federal contract in the first place.

3.  **Detailed analysis of whether there is direct or indirect impact:**
    The executive order has an **indirect but significant impact** on the policy.

    *   **Direct Impact:** The EO does not directly alter the day-to-day procedures outlined in the COR Desk Guide for managing a building services contract (e.g., how to inspect facilities, approve invoices, or monitor performance). The EO's primary impact is on the pre-award phase, where a Contracting Officer (CO) determines vendor eligibility.

    *   **Indirect Impact:** The policy is part of the GSA's overall federal procurement framework, which is holistically governed by executive orders. The GSA, as a federal agency, is bound to implement EO 14263. This means that all GSA procurement activities, including those for building services, must now comply with this new eligibility restriction. While the COR's guide is a post-award document, the COR is an integral part of the acquisition team. The agency's implementation of the EO may result in updated training, reporting requirements, or new clauses in contracts that the COR would then be responsible for monitoring. Therefore, the regulatory environment in which this policy guide exists and is applied is fundamentally altered by the EO.

4.  **Key language or provisions that support your determination:**
    *   **Policy Language:** The title "COR Desk Guide | Building Services Contracts" and the text "Contract administration for PBS Contracting" clearly place the document within the federal contracting lifecycle.
    *   **EO Language:** The EO states that certain entities "should not have access to our Nation's secrets, nor should their conduct be subsidized by Federal taxpayer funds or contracts." A "Building Services Contract" is a clear example of a subsidy via "Federal taxpayer funds or contracts." The EO's prohibition directly applies to the type of instrument the policy guide is designed to manage.

5.  **Any nuances or edge cases considered in your assessment:**
    The primary nuance is the distinction between the pre-award (contractor selection) and post-award (contract administration) phases. One could argue the policy is "Not Affected" because a COR only manages a contract after it has been awarded, and the EO is about who can be awarded a contract.

    However, this view is too narrow. The entire procurement system must adapt to the EO. An edge case could arise where a prime contractor for building services subcontracts work to a firm like Susman Godfrey. A COR's administrative duties could include reviewing and monitoring subcontractor arrangements, making the EO's prohibitions directly relevant to their oversight responsibilities in that specific scenario. Because the policy exists within a system that is unequivocally affected by the EO, the policy itself must be flagged as "Affected" to ensure compliance and potential future updates.

Section 106 requires agencies to consider the effects of their proposed undertaking on properties listed or eligible for listing in the National Register and to provide the Council, the SHPO and other consulting parties a reasonable opportunity to comment on the undertaking. GSA'S HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROGRAM 1. Mission a. Public Buildings Service mission The Public Buildings Service (PBS) provides workspace for Federal employees in both Federal Government-owned and leased buildings. PBS real estate management activities include acquisition of sites and buildings, construction, leasing, repair, alteration, and maintenance. Within GSA's real estate inventory are many properties significant in American history, architecture, archeology, engineering, and culture. GSA planning, design, construction, and disposal processes have the potential to affect the integrity of historic properties, including both those under Federal jurisdiction, custody and control as well as other properties. Common cultural property affected by GSA activity includes archeological artifacts and other resources discovered during GSA construction projects, significant properties controlled, leased or acquired by GSA, and historic districts, sites and buildings adjoining GSA activity. b. Agencywide coordination GSA s national historic preservation program serves as a focal point for the development of strategies to facilitate agencywide compliance with the spirit and substance of preservation laws and directives. The office of the FPO, located in the GSA headquarters of PBS, Office of Architecture and Engineering, Center for Historic Buildings, is responsible for providing agencywide access to preservation-related information and support. This requires establishing cross-business and cross-regional lines of communication and determining which types of communication will most effectively convey different types of information. c. Agencywide knowledge building Providing employees with access to information on historic buildings, preservation procedures and guidance requires close coordination between GSA s national and regional preservation programs and its Service and Staff Offices. Establishing information management standards for data uniformity, accuracy and continuity requires structured regional and national office interaction and procedures to facilitate quality control. Incorporating Federal stewardship goals into GSA s business mission requires integrating preservation-related information systems and business-related information systems, such as GSA real estate, asset business planning, engineering evaluation, project information, and other databases. 24 d. Promoting efficient use of agency resources Supporting GSA s business goal of cost effectively providing quality workspace requires a nationally coordinated effort to promote knowledge exchange, to develop, document and disseminate best practices, and to eliminate redundant effort. e. Promoting public benefit from Federal efforts GSA strives, while meeting its mission, to create opportunities for public benefit from efforts and investments in which GSA plays a role. To the greatest extent possible, GSA s preservation program makes its historic building documentation, guidance and publications available to researchers and the general public through GSA s preservation program website and partnering arrangements with other Federal agencies and nonprofit organizations. GSA s national and regional preservation programs cooperate to facilitate public access to culturally significant property and public spaces important to the community. 2. Responsibilities a. Agency responsibilities under NHPA It is GSA s responsibility to determine whether real property that it manages or that may be affected by GSA action may be eligible for listing in the National Register and to seek alternatives that avoid, minimize or mitigate adverse effects upon the qualities that may qualify such properties for listing in the National Register in accordance with applicable regulations (36 C.F.R.   800.4 and 800.6, respectively). Many GSA-managed buildings are included in the National Register. The definition of historic property under NHPA also includes properties that are eligible for the National Register, whether or not they have been nominated for inclusion. Federal agencies are responsible for evaluating properties that may be eligible for listing in the National Register and determining the effect that agency actions may have on them. b. Agency responsibility outside of NHPA GSA has responsibilities with respect to certain kinds of historic and cultural resources, even if they are not eligible for listing in the National Register. Consideration of historic properties under NHPA does not necessarily satisfy all of GSA s legal responsibilities, such as compliance with NEPA. While most obligations relate to GSA s responsibilities under NHPA and E.O.s 11593, 12072, 13006, and 13287, others relate to statutes governing specific types of resources, such as underwater artifacts or human remains. 25 c. Public Buildings Service National and Regional Program Offices 1) All affected PBS national and regional program offices must develop plans, in coordination with the FPO, to implement this order. PBS Assistant Commissioners, Regional Commissioners and regional business line directors must take immediate steps to implement the provisions of this order. 2) It is the responsibility of each region within GSA to identify, evaluate, protect, and enhance districts, sites, structures, buildings, and objects significant in American history, architecture, archeology, and culture. These properties include those that are listed in, determined to be eligible for listing in or that may be eligible for listing in the National Register. 3) GSA must consider the needs of Native Americans, Alaska Natives and Native Hawaiians in the practice of their traditional religions. To protect Native American religious cultural rites and practices, religious leaders or other native leaders (or their representatives) must be consulted concerning areas of potential conflict arising from the management of properties under GSA s jurisdiction, custody or control, and efforts must be made to eliminate or reduce such conflicts. 4) Avoidance of adverse effects to historic and cultural properties must always be attempted. When avoidance of adverse effects is not economically feasible or technically prudent, or when factors related to an undertaking from the standpoint of overall public benefit warrant alternatives that may result in adverse effects, such effects must be minimized to the extent possible. If the adverse effects cannot be avoided or minimized, then the adverse effects must be mitigated. See chapter 4,  Regulatory Compliance Procedures.  5) Compliance with Section 106 of NHPA, E.O.s 11593, 12072, 13006, 13287, 13990, 14057, and 14091, implementing regulations set forth at 36 C.F.R. part 800, and related laws and directives must be integrated with other environmental considerations under NEPA and 40 C.F.R.   1502.25(a) of the Council on Environmental Quality's regulations implementing NEPA. All Services and Staff Offices are responsible for timely Section 106 compliance for each National Register or National Register-Eligible Property that may be affected by its undertakings, even if an EIS or an Environmental Assessment (EA) is not required by NEPA. Activities meeting NEPA Categorical Exclusion criteria must also be evaluated for potential effects that may trigger Section 106 compliance requirements. d. Regional Historic Preservation Officer The RHPO directs GSA s historic preservation program at the regional level and is responsible for coordinating day-to-day regional compliance with relevant historic preservation laws, regulations, orders, and directives. The RHPO acts as the liaison between the RC and the FPO and the SHPO, the THPO, the Council, and related local organizations. The RHPO, at a minimum, must meet the applicable Secretary of the Interior's Historic Preservation Professional Qualification Standards. The RHPO also must have expert technical knowledge of architectural conservation and rehabilitation principles and practices and demonstrated skill in building interpersonal relations to guide GSA project teams effectively, articulate complex positions persuasively and influence Section 106 consultation outcomes positively. The RHPO must be organizationally positioned and given authority to lead and manage actively the regional preservation program and implement national preservation policies and initiatives. Unless it can be demonstrated, with the concurrence of the PBS Commissioner and the FPO, that the RHPO is able to fulfill all required duties of the position in a part-time capacity, the position requires a full-time specialist functioning in a senior staff capacity. In carrying out these duties, the RHPO is responsible for: 1) Initiating consultation with the appropriate SHPO and THPO at the earliest appropriate stage in planning or consideration of an undertaking, prior to any action that may limit consideration of alternatives or mitigation measures. Current inventory of archeological artifacts and other cultural resources, including type, source, volume, and storage location, as required by 36 C.F.R. part 79. 2) Online accessibility To facilitate efficient access to building information and guidance, provision for online access to available guidance will continue to play an integral role in GSA s preservation program. Architectural images Architectural photographs provide critical information required by project teams, decision makers and others responsible for preserving GSA historic buildings. Appropriately detailed images inform historically accurate restoration and repair in accordance with the Secretary s Standards. Keeping historic buildings occupied and viable often requires targeted marketing that relies on high-quality images, including graphic simulations showing how spaces will appear after reinvestment. Federal risk management and continuous operation directives underscore GSA s responsibility for documenting historic buildings and providing remote access to information needed when buildings are damaged by circumstances out of the Federal Government s control. Reduced physical access to buildings due to enhanced security, travel funding limitations and other reasons increases the need for detailed visual documentation to meet GSA compliance responsibilities within limited time frames. 1) GSA s national preservation program maintains a historic building image archive and partnership with the Library of Congress to provide online access to architectural photographs in the public domain that document Federal public buildings. The national preservation program works with regional project teams to document completed preservation projects at buildings of exceptional significance in documentary films that are made available online. The program also provides guidance for documentation of historic buildings, sites, archeological artifacts, and cultural resources. 2) GSA regional preservation staff help regional program offices to use and build upon available visual documentation in connection with projects and activities involving historic buildings and to inform future projects. Visual documentation supporting the preservation of GSA historic buildings includes historic photographs and drawings, architectural photographs documenting current conditions, photogrammetric images and laser scan point cloud data for three-dimensional documentation, video, animated renderings, and Building Information Models. GSA national and regional program offices are encouraged to cooperate in 37 achieving the greatest possible value from GSA documentation efforts by: a) Specifying that contracts including architectural photography meet or exceed National Register standards and allow GSA use for agency purposes; b) Maintaining images in archival electronic file formats to enable future retrieval and reproduction without loss of quality or information; c) Conforming Building Information Model data to open standards for interoperability using nonproprietary file formats; and d) Maintaining databases containing architectural images with any documentation required for future migration and retrieval. d. Historic Building Documentation Resource HBDR serves a larger purpose as GSA s central repository for visual and narrative building documentation, including individual BPPs, HSRs, National Register nominations, and related studies key to maintaining and preserving historic buildings. HBDR provides a standardized system for the analysis, treatment and management of individual buildings, groups of buildings and the overall GSA historic building inventory. 1) Building Preservation Plans, Historic Structure Reports and related studies. GSA uses BPPs and HSRs to identify the qualities and elements that contribute to the historic character of individual buildings and to guide change accordingly. The HSR is the standard document used in Federal and non-Federal preservation to guide changes to, and the care of, historic buildings. HSRs include, at a minimum, a comprehensive survey and analysis of existing spaces and conditions, with detailed recommendations for treatment and maintenance. The BPP was developed to address GSA project team needs and ensure shared access by all PBS employees to basic historic building information. 2) Both HSRs and BPPs graphically delineate the architectural hierarchy of spaces in each building to show which areas require special care and which can accommodate greater change without compromising the building s historic integrity. Both documents provide specific recommendations regarding the care and treatment of historic materials and spaces. Data in BPPs and HSRs also can 38 be used to assist GSA in making decisions regarding investment in and utilization of historic properties. 3) Other technical studies and guidance. Technical guidance provided in the HBDR and GSA website will be regularly reviewed and updated, as necessary, by qualified staff so that the guidance remains sound and valid. e. Developing strategies to promote the use and viability of historic buildings GSA national and regional programs must cooperate to develop strategies to promote the use, full occupancy and economic viability of historic buildings, especially monumental or architecturally exceptional historic buildings representing the Federal Government s public building legacy. f. Promoting broad-based stewardship 1) Internal advocacy. GSA national and regional programs must develop educational programs and material using a variety of media to promote recognition and appreciation of GSA's historic buildings and stewardship efforts. Special attention should be given to historic buildings of exceptional architectural or historic significance and buildings considered focal points of the communities in which they are located. 2) External advocacy. GSA national and regional preservation programs must include activities for actively developing and maintaining positive relationships with external oversight groups, preservation organizations and the public. GSA preservation homepages should include building documentation commonly requested by the public and up-to-date information on projects and issues of substantial public interest.
